page.title: 03BURGH CASTLE
page.content: The walls of the Romano-British fort (Gariannonym) at Burgh Castle stand,in an impressive state of repair, overlooking the marshlands of the Waveney valley.Built of local flint and tiles they stand tall,bounded by circular watch towers.The wooden superstructure has long since decayed,but whether the absent West wall ever existed or has suffered a similar fate is not known. Three walls enclose the site which has been extensively excavated but is now an arable field.Details and finds are displayed in the Castle Museum Norwich.Just visible within the walls are the remains of a Norman castle motte.The situation of Gariannonym is explained by the fact that it once looked over a shallow sea towards Caister, where another Roman site may be found.
